title: Frequency-domain computation of inflow broadband noise due to interaction of a rectilinear cascade of flat plates with incident turbulence
abstract: This paper deals with the broadband noise due to the interaction between convected turbulent gusts and a rectilinear cascade of flat plates bounded by two parallel walls. An analytic formulation for the acoustic power spectrum due to this turbulence-cascade interaction is derived, which can be used to assess the effects of the span-wise wavenumber components of ingesting turbulent gust on the overall acoustic power spectrum. This three-dimensional theory is based on the two-dimensional theory of Cheong et al. (2006, 2009). The three-dimensional model is shown to provide a close fit to the measured spectrum of rotor-stator interaction. The predictions using this three-dimensional model are also compared with those using the previous two-dimensional model by Cheong et al. (2006; 2009). Through this comparison, it is found that the contributions to the acoustic power of the span-wise wavenumber components of incident turbulent gust are increased as the frequency is augmented, which is mainly due to three-dimensional dispersion-relation characteristics of acoustic waves. This implies that the number of incident turbulent gust modes directly involved in generating cut-on acoustic waves increases as the frequency increases. Therefore, in the lower frequency range, three-dimensional acoustic power is less than its corresponding two-dimensional one, whereas, as the frequency increases, the three-dimensional acoustic power spectrum closely follows those of two-dimension. The formulation is also used to make a parametric study about the effects on the power spectrum of the blade number, stagger angle, gap-chord ratio, and Mach number.

motivations: There is a need to understand and predict the broadband noise generated by the interaction between convected turbulent gusts and a rectilinear cascade of flat plates.
Existing two-dimensional models may not accurately capture the effects of span-wise wavenumber components of incident turbulent gusts on the overall acoustic power spectrum.
objectives: Derive an analytic formulation for the acoustic power spectrum due to turbulence-cascade interaction in a three-dimensional setting.
Assess the effects of span-wise wavenumber components of incident turbulent gusts on the overall acoustic power spectrum.
Compare the predictions of the three-dimensional model with those of a previous two-dimensional model and with experimental measurements.
methods: Extend the two-dimensional theory of Cheong et al. (2006, 2009) to a three-dimensional setting.
Use the derived formulation to make predictions of the acoustic power spectrum for various parameters, including blade number, stagger angle, gap-chord ratio, and Mach number.
Compare the predictions with experimental measurements and with those of the previous two-dimensional model.
results: The three-dimensional model provides a close fit to the measured spectrum of rotor-stator interaction.
The contributions of span-wise wavenumber components of incident turbulent gusts to the acoustic power increase with frequency.
The three-dimensional acoustic power spectrum closely follows the two-dimensional one at higher frequencies, but is lower at lower frequencies.
llama_json.research_subject: Frequency-domain computation of inflow broadband noise due to interaction of a rectilinear cascade of flat plates with incident turbulence

motivations: Understanding the broadband noise due to the interaction between convected turbulent gusts and a rectilinear cascade of flat plates is crucial for noise reduction in various applications.
Existing two-dimensional models may not fully capture the effects of the span-wise wavenumber components of ingesting turbulent gust on the overall acoustic power spectrum.
objectives: Derive an analytic formulation for the acoustic power spectrum due to turbulence-cascade interaction.
Compare the predictions of the new three-dimensional model with those of the previous two-dimensional model.
Conduct a parametric study on the effects of the blade number, stagger angle, gap-chord ratio, and Mach number on the power spectrum.
methods: Develop a three-dimensional theory based on the two-dimensional theory of Cheong et al. (2006, 2009) to model the turbulence-cascade interaction.
Validate the three-dimensional model by comparing its predictions with the measured spectrum of rotor-stator interaction and with the predictions of the two-dimensional model.
Use the derived formulation to conduct a parametric study on the effects of various factors on the power spectrum.
results: The three-dimensional model provides a close fit to the measured spectrum of rotor-stator interaction.
The contributions to the acoustic power of the span-wise wavenumber components of incident turbulent gust increase as the frequency is augmented.

In the lower frequency range, three-dimensional acoustic power is less than its corresponding two-dimensional one, but as the frequency increases, the three-dimensional acoustic power spectrum closely follows those of two-dimension.
openai_json.research_subject: Frequency-domain computation of inflow broadband noise due to turbulence-cascade interaction

motivations: Understanding broadband noise generation from turbulence-cascade interactions is crucial for noise reduction in turbomachinery applications.
Existing two-dimensional models may not fully capture the three-dimensional effects of span-wise turbulent gust components on acoustic power generation.
objectives: Develop an analytic three-dimensional formulation for acoustic power spectrum from turbulence-cascade interaction in a rectilinear cascade of flat plates.
Assess the effects of span-wise wavenumber components of turbulent gusts on acoustic power generation and compare with two-dimensional models.
methods: Extend the two-dimensional theory of Cheong et al. to three dimensions for modeling turbulence-cascade interaction acoustics.
Validate the model against measured rotor-stator interaction spectra and compare predictions with previous two-dimensional models.
Conduct parametric studies examining the effects of blade number, stagger angle, gap-chord ratio, and Mach number on power spectrum.
results: Three-dimensional model provides close agreement with measured rotor-stator interaction spectra and reveals frequency-dependent contributions of span-wise turbulent gust components.
At lower frequencies, three-dimensional acoustic power is less than two-dimensional predictions, while at higher frequencies they converge due to increased cut-on acoustic wave modes.
The formulation enables systematic evaluation of design parameters on broadband noise generation in turbomachinery cascades.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Three-dimensional frequency-domain modeling of broadband noise from turbulence-cascade interaction
